A ring R is called commutative if the multiplication is commutative.
System of Generators of an Ideal

Let $\mathfrak{a}$ be an ideal of a ring $R$. A family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$ of elements in $\mathfrak{a}$ is called a system of generators of $\mathfrak{a}$ if $\mathfrak{a}=\sum_{i \in I} R a_{i}$, i.e., if $\mathfrak{a}$ coincides with the ideal generated by the family $\left(a_{i}\right)_{i \in I}$.
Does the concept of a/an Commutative Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a System of Generators of an Ideal requires the concept of a ring, as it involves an ideal of a ring and elements of that ring generating the ideal. However, the definition does not specify that the ring must be commutative; it only requires the existence of a ring structure. The concept of a Commutative Ring specifically adds the condition that the multiplication operation within the ring is commutative. This additional property of commutativity is not necessary for the definition of a System of Generators of an Ideal, which can be applied to any ring, whether commutative or not. Therefore, the concept of a Commutative Ring is not necessary for the definition of a System of Generators of an Ideal to make sense.
